intro: Acinos acuminatus, commonly known as the sharpleaf acino, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of small tubular and ray flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, open habitats such as grasslands and slopes, preferring well-drained soils. Its leaves are narrow and pointed, giving it the common name "sharpleaf," and it produces small, yellowish flowers in the summer. Acinos acuminatus is known for its resilience to drought and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments.
